definition: to dig into piles of outdated writings (idiom); to study old books and papers
to drill/to bore/to get into/to make one's way into/to enter (a hole)/to thread one's way through/to study intensively/to dig into/to curry favor for personal gain
variant of 鑽|钻[zuan4]
an auger/diamond
happening/instance/reason/cause/intentional/former/old/friend/therefore/hence/(of people) to die, dead
paper/CL:張|张[zhang1],沓[da2]/classifier for documents, letter etc
variant of 紙|纸[zhi3]
to pile up/to heap up/a mass/pile/heap/stack/large amount
to study/to engage in scholarship
a pile of old books
pedant
diligently
lit. to wave around one's bookbag (idiom)/fig. to show off one's erudition/a person who does so
pedant/old fogey
lit. not requiring a detailed understanding (idiom); only looking for an overview/not bothered with the details/superficial/content with shallow understanding
without proof one can't believe it (idiom)
to pick up what others say (idiom); to pass off other people's opinions as one's own/to parrot
conservative and unable to adapt (idiom)
not paying attention to anything (idiom); to idle time away
to swallow ancient learning without digesting it (idiom)/to be pedantic without having a mastery of one's subject
to make a living/to strive to earn a living
lit. to build a cart behind closed doors/to be overly subjective and disregard the outside world (idiom)
to interpret and make glossaries and commentaries on classic texts
to pluck a pearl from the black dragon (idiom, from Zhuangzi); fig. to pick out the salient points (from a tangled situation)/to see through to the nub
